article_title: The Ultimate Guide to World Cup 2026
article_content:
The 2026 FIFA World Cup is set to be the largest and most ambitious edition in the tournament's history. For the first time, the "beautiful game" will be hosted across an entire continent, with the United States, Mexico, and Canada serving as joint hosts.

Starting on June 11, 2026, the tournament will break several long-standing traditions, offering more teams and more matches than ever before. If you are planning to attend, you can already view the World Cup 2026 schedule to see when your favourite teams are playing.

1. A Massive Expansion: 48 Teams

The most significant change for 2026 is the expansion of the field. After decades of a 32-team format, the tournament will now feature 48 nations. This expansion means:

  • 104 Total Matches: Up from the previous 64.

  • New Group Structure: 12 groups of four teams each.

  • Extended Knockout Phase: A new "Round of 32" will be introduced before the Round of 16.

2. Iconic Venues & Cities

Matches will be played across 16 host cities. While the U.S. will host the majority of the games, Mexico and Canada will hold key opening fixtures. Fans looking to secure their spot at these historic venues can browse the World Cup 2026 tickets selection to find seats in their preferred host city.

CountryKey Host CitiesNotable StadiumMexicoMexico City, GuadalajaraEstadio AztecaUSANY/NJ, LA, Miami, DallasMetLife Stadium (The Final)CanadaToronto, VancouverBC Place

Export to Sheets

3. Experience the Action Live

The tournament officially kicks off at the historic Estadio Azteca in Mexico City. After a grueling five-week schedule, the world will turn its eyes to MetLife Stadium in New Jersey to crown the world champion. For those wanting a more luxurious experience, there are various World Cup 2026 hospitality packages available, offering premium seating and exclusive amenities.

With debutants like Uzbekistan and Jordan joining established giants, the 2026 World Cup promises to be a global celebration of football on an unprecedented scale.
